snippet.textDisplay:
I'm an Apple fanboy but to be fair this time Apple really needs to rethink their pricing strategy. In short time the company will benefit from it but in long time the company will suffer a lot from the loss of customer base.
Apple can rob NOW because they know their customer have to rely on macOS to do their job. However, what else can you do to force people buy your products after you've pushed your customers out as the price goes higher and higher?
snippet.textOriginal:
I'm an Apple fanboy but to be fair this time Apple really needs to rethink their pricing strategy. In short time the company will benefit from it but in long time the company will suffer a lot from the loss of customer base.

snippet.textDisplay: What a fucking price scam this garbage from Apple is.
snippet.textOriginal: What a fucking price scam this garbage from Apple is.

snippet.textDisplay:
Sigh...

I am disappointed that this isn't as good as it could be. It's got a lot of good, but the price is insane for what you actually get.

They had an option to simply live with the 20% markup, and then throw insane specs into it at every corner and make it easy and maintainable.

Their goal should have been:

Any professional that wants high end performance, simply pay the 20% apple tax, and you can have a great MAC with that performance.

But no. They went insane with their markup instead of trying to get it into every professional's hands.

$5k for 768gb of ram aftermarket, when apple charges $10k. For FUCK sake. A Vega 2?

For 2400? Fuck....

And the afterburner is simply a DECODER and doesn't assist with other formats / encoding?

GROSS.
snippet.textOriginal:
Sigh... 

I am disappointed that this isn't as good as it could be. It's got a lot of good, but the price is insane for what you actually get.

They had an option to simply live with the 20% markup, and then throw insane specs into it at every corner and make it easy and maintainable. 

Their goal should have been: 

Any professional that wants high end performance, simply pay the 20% apple tax, and you can have a great MAC with that performance. 

But no. They went insane with their markup instead of trying to get it into every professional's hands. 

$5k for 768gb of ram aftermarket, when apple charges $10k. For FUCK sake. A Vega 2? 

For 2400? Fuck....

And the afterburner is simply a DECODER and doesn't assist with other formats / encoding? 

GROSS.

snippet.textDisplay: Oracle and its Sun engineers could produce a super fast workstation but even Sun Microsystems didn't seem serious about its Intel-based workstations (they had a chip memory Pci Accelerator card but didn't think of placing them in their workstations). Exadata yes, workstations no.

snippet.textDisplay:
Linus, what downtime are you talking about at 11:45? It doesnt take more than a day for a technician to upgrade a machine. If multiple machines need upgrades, then they can either do 1 at a time, or have multiple technicians upgrade them at the same time.
Yes it will cost them SOME money, but I bet you it will still be less than the Apple tax.

Overall, this is just Apple ripping idiots off. Professional designers and editors that just dont have any computer building experience whatsoever, and are afraid to let someone upgrade their machines.
Even so however, they still have the option to buy from other system integrators.

 Whatever, I dont exactly care, but Apple is still greedy as fuck.
snippet.textOriginal:
Linus, what downtime are you talking about at 11:45? It doesnt take more than a day for a technician to upgrade a machine. If multiple machines need upgrades, then they can either do 1 at a time, or have multiple technicians upgrade them at the same time.
Yes it will cost them SOME money, but I bet you it will still be less than the Apple tax.

Overall, this is just Apple ripping idiots off. Professional designers and editors that just dont have any computer building experience whatsoever, and are afraid to let someone upgrade their machines.
Even so however, they still have the option to buy from other system integrators.

 Whatever, I dont exactly care, but Apple is still greedy as fuck.

snippet.textDisplay: 10:35 that's where you see what some 4K bluray buyers know but most people don't "4k" movies especially all recent are in 2K, for example the last MCUs are noticeably blurry even on blurays compared to old pre-digital era 4K remasters (streamed 4K is heavily compressed so we don't even talk about that) a number to give you an idea, for 1 frame of Frozen (24 frame per second) it took 132hours of rendering ! thats 132 days of encoding for 1s of movie (they use hundreds or thousands of computers rendering each 1 frame but still....) so real 4K is hardly ever used except for movies with low VFX because of the time and ressources it takes,time is especially a problem, needless to say 8K is madness and I really hope this time someone will call the bs

snippet.textDisplay: I hope all the poor-shaming bastards who buy the lowest teir of these for bragging rights can laugh when my Ryzen 5 3600 system with 16 GB of RAM running Linux outperforms it for audio and video rendering and playback in Reaper and DaVinci Resolve, respectively, and can run more simultaneous CPU intensive VST plugins simultaneously for the former. Linux has been giving lower input monitoring latency with ALSA than both CoreAudio AND ASIO with LTS and Mainline Kernels since 2010, even with the Windows version of Reaper running in Wine. Now that there is a native version, the latency is even lower. Obviously, Linus did the poor shaming to be tongue and cheek, some people really think that way, and those fine folks need their knee caps to have a long conversation with a ball pin hammer and a metalworking mallet, in that order. Repeatedly, just because that crap is annoying, more so than anything else.
snippet.textOriginal: I hope all the poor-shaming bastards who buy the lowest teir of these for bragging rights can laugh when my Ryzen 5 3600 system with 16 GB of RAM running Linux outperforms it for audio and video rendering and playback in Reaper and DaVinci Resolve, respectively, and can run more simultaneous CPU intensive VST plugins simultaneously for the former. Linux has been giving lower input monitoring latency with ALSA than both CoreAudio AND ASIO with LTS and Mainline Kernels since 2010, even with the Windows version of Reaper running in Wine. Now that there is a native version, the latency is even lower. Obviously, Linus did the poor shaming to be tongue and cheek, some people really think that way, and those fine folks need their knee caps to have a long conversation with a ball pin hammer and a metalworking mallet, in that order. Repeatedly, just because that crap is annoying, more so than anything else.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hey @Linus,
Apple does not use the W-3275 as 28-Core, but the W-3275M - which starts around $7500. The W-3275 only supports up to 1TB of RAM, so if you want the full 1.5TB of RAM, you need the bigger CPU. But for everything below 1TB, one can save the about $4000.
snippet.textOriginal:
Hey @Linus,
Apple does not use the W-3275 as 28-Core, but the W-3275M - which starts around $7500. The W-3275 only supports up to 1TB of RAM, so if you want the full 1.5TB of RAM, you need the bigger CPU. But for everything below 1TB, one can save the about $4000.

snippet.textDisplay: Do these VFX studios not have IT departments full of nerds like us to build and deploy comparable/more powerful machines at a moments notice? Anyone can put together a bunch of these in a weekend. Even if these studios NEED OS X, can't they just pay the IT guys to upgrade the machines for them? It will take literally minutes with how easy Apple has made these things to take apart. All products would still have warranties.  Unless it is difficult to source a Xeon or that much RAM at short notice I can't say why it would be too difficult. They would probably save money paying the IT guys instead of pimping out their machines. I realize that in large production houses the cost of these computers is probably just a drop in the bucket but still. I'm sure Apple has done massive amounts of research on their target audience for these machines and they will sell but damn, what a waste of money imo. (Opinion of uninformed filthy casual)
snippet.textOriginal: Do these VFX studios not have IT departments full of nerds like us to build and deploy comparable/more powerful machines at a moments notice? snippet.textDisplay: So this thing is lazer focused on not just business customers, but specifically companies who contract for Disney(an early Apple investor) and related studios. Anyone else buying it is just wasting their money. It does make sense considering Apple's relationship with Disney specifically and the fact that a similar thing happened with AWS. It was originally something internal for Amazon itself but they had a ton of computation left over so they started selling it. This might have been an internal thing for some huge client but they are allowing others to buy.

I use my own monitor stands.

snippet.textDisplay:
I love hearing "Hollywood studios" as a marketing term.

There are roughly 3 kind of VFX companies in the world:

1, Small sized, around 10-15 workstations together. They do motion graphics for TV, maybe have a separate grading station or a couple of editors. They're a potential buyer for this product if they have unlimited money. Similar to LTT.

2, Medium sized animation or VFX companies (up to 200-300 workstations let's say) - they might buy a couple of these for running dailies or vfx editing/grading for client facing operations. Less than 1% of their computers would be something like this. But then most of their workflow is on Linux.

3, Large vfx factories with actual Hollywood movies: 2-3000 people (worldwide). They will buy about 10 of these if..they probably won't. Maybe for onset work it could be useful.

So where is the market?

I tell you where: overly egoistic influencer type "content creators" (aka youtubers).
